results.body:
A shark attacked a Portland man who was surfing near Indian Beach on Monday, according to the Oregon State Police.

Early information indicates the shark bit Joseph Tanner, 29, on his upper thigh and lower leg, the Oregon State Police said in a news release. He was flown to Portland's Legacy Emanuel Medical Center for treatment of serious injuries, troopers said.

A medical center spokesman said Tanner was under evaluation in the emergency room, as of about 7 p.m. Authorities were dispatched to the beach, a popular surfing destination that's part of Ecola State Park, about three hours prior.

There hasn't been a shark attack off the Oregon coast since 2013, according to two online databases. The November 2013 attack happened off Gleneden Beach in Lincoln County.

Of 28 previous Oregon shark attacks listed in the Global Shark Attack File database, only one has been fatal. Two people died in a 1975 attack after they were thrown into the water during a boating accident, the database's director said.

Ralph S. Collier, director of the Global Shark Attack File and president of the Shark Research Committee, said the pair was bit by blue sharks either before or after death. 

Each of the 27 previous authenticated, unprovoked Oregon shark attacks have involved great white sharks, Collier said. There have been a few provoked shark attacks over the years, he said, but those cases are not included in the database.

An Oregon State Police spokesman said investigators don't know what kind of shark attacked Tanner. 

Shark attacks off the West Coast most often happen from August through October, Collier said. Attacks are rare, he said, and more often than not happen in locations where there have been previous attacks.

"Even with these increases in both populations — humans and sharks — we still have very few of these when you look at the overall picture," he said.

Troopers are investigating Monday's attack.

— Jim Ryan
jryan@oregonian.com
503-221-8005; @Jimryan015
results.title: Shark bites surfer off Oregon coast
results.html: Early information indicates the shark bit Joseph Tanner, 29, on his upper thigh and lower leg, according to the Oregon State Police.

results.body:
Fat Cupcake opened its doors in Southeast Portland about a month ago. The new location, the company's second, serves pastries and a wide variety of cupcakes out of a small storefront on 72nd Avenue.

In early September, however, not long after opening, the shop ran into some trouble when Portland customers became upset by the "Mr. President" cupcake, described on the menu as "Oreo (™) Cookie baked inside white cake, cookies n' cream buttercream."

On Yelp, one reviewer wrote, "Very troubling. They were serving a cupcake called the 'Mr. President' that had an Oreo cookie inside. When I tried to point out the racism implied, they claimed that 'our current president loves Oreos.'"

When we called to ask Anjelica Hayes, the owner of Fat Cupcake, about the accusations of racism, she responded, "I have been asked this so many times."

She said over the phone Monday, unequivocally, that she isn't racist.

For one thing, she said, "I myself am black."

Hayes said she is a born and raised Portlander. She said she is very involved in the community and has even started something she called, "our 'Piece of Cake' movement."

"We have driven around Portland to give away cakes to the homeless," she said, "and donated thousands of cupcakes to the community."

Hayes told us that the name for the cupcake came because she wanted to call it something to honor what a great cupcake it is.

"What sounds like it would be really fancy?" she said. "We thought of the presidential office."

"I just thought it was an honorary name," she said. "I thought I'd be honored if someone named a cupcake after me."

She said that at one point someone told her that President Barack Obama's favorite cookie was the Oreo. "So we thought that was a cool coincidence," she said.

But since opening in Southeast Portland, Hayes said she's had to field questions about whether her cupcakes are racist. She also has a cupcake called "The Intern" that the same customer quoted above on Yelp took to be a slam on Monica Lewinsky. Hayes said it is not.

At least until the election is over, Hayes said, they have changed the name of the cupcake to a more generic title: "The Professional."

She said the cupcake, whatever it's called, is one of the store's most popular items.

-- Lizzy Acker

503-221-8052
lacker@oregonian.com, @lizzzyacker
results.title: Black-owned Portland cupcake shop accused of racism
results.html: An Oreo-flavored cupcake called "Mr. President" has caused a stir in Southeast Portland.

results.body:
Update: What a ballgame. The San Francisco Giants rallied to beat the Chicago Cubs 6-5 in 13 innings in Game 3 of the National League Division Series Monday night. Joe Panik's double scored Brandon Crawford with the winning run in the bottom of the 13th. The Cubs now lead the series 2-1.

The Cubs tied the game 5-5 on a two-run home run by Kris Bryant in the top of the ninth inning. The Giants had rallied to take a 5-3 lead on the Cubs in the bottom of the eighth inning. Conor Gillaspie struck the big blow for the Giants with a two-run triple off Cubs closer Aroldis Chapman.

The Cubs took a 3-0 lead in the second inning on a three-run homer from Cubs pitcher Jake Arrieta. Giants ace Madison Bumgarner lasted just five innings, allowing seven hits and three runs. 

Pregame: The San Francisco Giants will rely on ace Madison Bumgarner to extend their season Monday night when they take on the Chicago Cubs in Game 3 of their 2016 National League Division Series.

Cubs fans have waited a long time to quit waiting on next year, and Chicago's latest quest is a win away from overcoming the Giants' even-year magic. The Cubs lead 2-0 in the best-of-five NLDS, but don't expect them to take San Francisco lightly — the Giants are 9-0 in elimination games under manager Bruce Bochy, and Bumgarner is pitching in Game 3. "We'd be foolish to be overconfident about this situation," Cubs manager Joe Maddon said. "They're really good, they've done this before."

Get the latest NLDS Game 3 updates live in the box score above and real-time analysis in the comments thread below. Here's everything you need to know about San Francisco vs. Chicago Game 3:

What: Chicago (103-58, 46-34 away) at San Francisco (87-75, 45-36 home)

When: 6:30 p.m. PT Monday, Oct. 10

Where: AT&T Park, San Francisco, California

TV: Fox Sports 1 (In Portland area: Comcast 408/723, CenturyLink 620/1620, DirecTV 219, Dish 150)

Watch online: Live stream available at FS1

Starting pitchers: 

Chicago – RH Jake Arrieta (18-8, 3.10 ERA)

San Francisco – LH Madison Bumgarner (15-9, 2.74)

Series: Cubs lead 2-0

More: Read the complete NLDS Game 3 preview

Full schedule for San Francisco vs. Chicago
results.title: San Francisco Giants stay alive, beat Chicago Cubs in 13 innings (10/10/16) | NLDS Game 3 box score, recap, stats
results.html: The Chicago Cubs lead 2-0 in their best-of-five NLDS with the Giants as the series shifts to San Francisco on Monday at 6:30 p.m. PT.
results.short_title: MLB playoffs: Giants stay alive, beat Cubs in 13 innings

results.body:
It was a strong year for Oregon-brewed fruit and wild beers at the 2016 Great American Beer Festival.  

The prestigious festival awarded 21 medals this year to beers brewed in Oregon, including nine bronze medals, seven silvers and five golds, according to the festival. 

But noticeably absent for the second year in a row was a medal in the American-Style India Pale Ale category. Oregon brought home the gold in both 2013 (Barley Brown's Pallet Jack IPA) and 2014 (Breakside IPA). Seattle's Georgetown Brewing Co. won the gold this year for their Bodhizafa IPA. 

Here's the full list of Oregon winners:

  • 10 Barrel Brewing Co. -- Gold -- P2P -- American-Style Stout
  • Alesong Brewing & Blending -- Gold -- Touch of Brett -- Brett Beer
  • Barley Brown's Beer -- Silver -- Shredder's Wheat -- American-Style Wheat Beer
  • Breakside Brewery -- Gold -- Breakside Rye Curious? -- Rye Beer
  • Breakside Brewery -- Silver -- Breakside ESB -- Classic English-Style Pale Ale
  • Breakside Brewery and Taproom -- Bronze -- Breakside Lunch Break ISA -- Australian-Style or International-Style Pale Ale
  • BTU Brasserie -- Bronze -- Butt-Ah Nut -- Pumpkin/Squash Beer
  • The Commons Brewery -- Bronze -- Creme de Peche -- Specialty Saison
  • The Commons Brewery -- Bronze -- Petite Classique -- Other Belgian-Style Ale
  • Craft Brew Alliance, Omission -- Bronze -- Lager -- American-Style Lager or Ice Lager or Malt Liquor
  • Craft Brew Alliance, Widmer -- Silver -- Drop Top Amber Ale -- Ordinary or Special Bitter
  • Great Notion Brewing -- Silver -- Heart of Gold -- American-Style Sour Ale
  • Groundbreaker Brewing -- Gold -- Dark Ale -- Gluten-free Beer
  • Flat Tail Brewing Co. -- Bronze -- DAM Wild: Marionberry Pink Peppercorn -- Mixed-Culture Brett Beer
  • Logsdon Farmhouse Ales -- Bronze -- Cerasus -- Belgian-Style Fruit Beer
  • Migration Brewing Co. -- Bronze -- Old Silenus Ale -- Old Ale or Strong Ale
  • Pelican Brewing -- Silver -- Pelicano Extra! -- American-Style or International-Style Pilsener
  • Sunriver Brewing -- Silver -- Rippin -- American-Style Strong Pale Ale
  • Three Creeks Production -- Gold -- FivePine Chocolate Porter -- Brown Porter
  • Two Kilts Brewing -- Silver -- Scottish Ale -- Scottish-Style Ale
  • Vertigo Brewing -- Bronze -- Apricot Cream Ale -- American-Style Fruit Beer

-- Samantha Bakall

sbakall@oregonian.com
Follow @sambakall
results.title: Oregon breweries bring home 21 medals from 2016 Great American Beer Festival
results.html: The prestigious festival awarded 21 medals this year to beers brewed in Oregon, including nine bronze medals, seven silvers and five golds.

results.body:
Oregon coaches have begun traveling out of town this week to recruit during UO's bye.

The Ducks will practice Tuesday and Thursday and lift weights three days this week, as well.

But mostly, they will spend their week attempting to recover mentally and physically from a 2-4 start, the worst by the program in 30 years.

What was said following Oregon's 70-21 loss to No. 5 Washington on Saturday:

Washington safety JoJo McIntosh, via USA Today:

"C'mon man! C'mon! That's too easy! It was too easy!"

Yahoo's Pat Forde: 

Yet (Charlie) Strong might have more security than Mark Helfrich, who is watching his Oregon program collapse around him with terrifying speed. The Ducks were atomized by Washington on Saturday, 70-21, their fourth straight loss. Oregon is immeasurably bad defensively and lacks the usual offensive firepower to compensate for it. The Ducks head into a bye week now, and staff changes would not be a shock – particularly on the defensive side of the ball.

After Oregon was ranked second and third in Dan Wolken of USA Today's weekly "Misery Index," UO earned dishonorable mention this week.

Part of Wolken's analysis:

Losing 70-21 on your home field to Washington is Duck Dysfunction of the highest order. It was apparent from the opening minutes Washington would be able to name its score, and after 682 yards of offense we can thank the Huskies for settling on a nice round number that drives home the point this should be unacceptable for Mark Helfrich and his coaching staff.

Read the rest here.

ESPN's Pac-12 Blog — like The Oregonian/OregonLive's own in-house rankings — slotted Oregon 12th in its conference power rankings. In doing so, it wrote:

The king is dead. Long live the king.

FOX Sports' Aaron Torres:

Following Saturday's embarrassing 70-21 loss to Washington, it's over for Helfrich. His time is ticking. It's not a matter of "when" he gets let go, but "if." This is a loss he will never recover from.

CBS Sports' Ben Kercheval:

The 2-4 Ducks have now been outscored 121-54 in their last two games to Washington State and Washington. This isn't just Oregon taking a step back in the post-Marcus Mariota years; there simply isn't that much high-end talent on this team. The defense is a mess and the switch at quarterback from Dakota Prukop to Justin Herbert did nothing to spark the offense. Will Oregon even be bowl eligible this year? It has to find four wins in a remaining schedule featuring Cal, Arizona State, USC, Stanford, Utah and Oregon State.

One weekly feature I check every Monday is USA Today's re-rank of all 128 Football Bowl Subdivision teams, which Paul Myerberg writes to provide a snapshot of the large national trends.

Oregon fell 23 spots to 89th this week, tied for the third-largest drop in the ranking.

In this case, the numbers said everything.

Here are today's links:

Oregon's Brady Hoke "will remember" Washington scoring 70

My attempt to analyze Oregon's loss to Washington, in 10 takeaways

Ken Goe: UW can win it all

Mark Helfrich says Oregon needs to get its collective mind right this week

Everything else Helfrich said Sunday in his press conference

UO has many issues right now, with few easy answers

The kid at QB is all right

Herbert is Oregon's ... Luke Skywalker?

Where is all the anger over this loss?

Some players "don't care" and that concerns UO

Miss any scores from the Top 25? All here

Marcus Mariota slows his sophomore slump with a nice performance

Pac-12 Power Rankings from the Oregonian/OregonLive staff

UO's postgame notes

-- Andrew Greif
agreif@oregonian.com
@andrewgreif
results.title: What national media, others are saying about Oregon's 'immeasurably bad' 2-4 start: Ducks rundown
results.html: Oregon is off to is worst start in 30 years after losing 70-21 to Washington on Saturday in Autzen Stadium.

results.body:
No matter how you want to slice this cantaloupe, it doesn't look appetizing.

At least not for Oregon fans. Not now.

The Ducks have lost four straight games, and their national standing has evaporated along with the slide.

Among the programs USA Today's Paul Myerberg ranks higher than the Ducks are Old Dominion, Colorado State, Central Florida, Akron, Western Kentucky, Army, Ohio and, well, you get the idea.

Myerberg has the Ducks higher than the Beavers. At this point of this season, I wouldn't.

I saw Oregon State beat Cal Saturday night by playing with the pride, poise and passion that seem to be lacking in Eugene.

So, what does it mean?

Maybe it's one of those seasons that has become a perfect storm of recruiting misses, poor veteran leadership and opponents who have been waiting eagerly for an opportunity to get their licks in on a program many believe was getting a little big for its britches.

Stuff happens, you know?

Sometimes the best way to fix things isn't to go into Celebrity Apprentice mode and fire everybody in sight.

That can take a one-season problem and make it worse.

Some say Oregon's descent began last year with defensive breakdowns in losses to Utah, Washington State and in the Alamo Bowl to TCU.

UO coach Mark Helfrich attempted to address that by changing defensive coordinators and switching schemes.

It's too early to pull the plug on the scheme. Defensive coordinator Brady Hoke hasn't had the opportunity to bring in the players to implement it.

Many current UO coaches were part of the staff during the golden run in which the Ducks twice played in the national title game. I don't believe they became incompetent in the interim.

If you think Chip Kelly is solely responsible for Oregon's recent success, you have to wonder what has happened to Kelly's coaching brilliance since he migrated to the NFL.

Kelly was fired from the Eagles and currently is 1-4 with the 49ers.

Look, I think Kelly is a very good coach. Maybe a great one. I covered the Ducks for two seasons when he was head coach. I thought he was a football savant.

But sometimes it's not all on the head coach.

OK, more links:

The Ducks sink to the cellar; how I voted in the Pac-12 Power Rankings (and why).

Here is the The O/Olive Power Rankings turned out.

For comparison purposes, here are the ESPN.com Pac-12 Power Rankings.

The Oregon Ducks are becoming a regular part of USA Today columnist Dan Wolken's weekly misery index, although this week the Ducks don't make the top five.

The Merc's Jon Wilner reviews the Pac-12's weekend and makes Oregon State his team of the week.

Andrew Nemec, The O's recruiting expert, has this interesting and informative analysis of Oregon's recruiting and how it ties into the team's current performance.

After being blown out the Huskies, the Ducks go to work on their psyche.

Helfrich's day-after presser as he looks back at the loss to Washington and ahead to the remainder of the season.

Oh my golly, the Huskies can win it all; it's one of my three takeaways from the weekend.

ESPN.com Pac-12 guru Ted Miller: Even the Huskies are surprised by how good the Huskies are.

This Washington team draws comparisons to the 1991 national champ.

In the bowl projections Jerry Palm does for CBSSports.com, the Huskies are in the College Football Playoff.

UW quarterback Jake Browning has the nation's best passer rating.

The TNT's John McGrath: Will this year's Heisman winner play quarterback in the Apple Cup?

Aaron Fentress of CSNNW.com: Justin Herbert has both a bright future and a steep learning curve.

Lots for the Ducks to fix during the bye week.

The O's Gina Mizell peeks back at the 10 moments that mattered in Oregon State's victory over Cal (slideshow).

Mizell's extended review of the Beavers' first Pac-12 win since 2014.

Mizell takes this look at Utah, which plays the Beavers Saturday afternoon at Reser Stadium.

A snapshot glance at the Beavers stack up statistically.

Beaver Nation is in full-scale celebration mode.

Injuries decimate Utah's running backs.

Slow starts plague the 5-1 Utes.

Wilner flunks the Cal Bears for their performance in Reser Stadium.

The Cougars head into Saturday's game with UCLA in control of their own destiny.

Washington State's defense wants to forge its own identity.

One-dimensional UCLA offense is hurting quarterback Josh Rosen.

UCLA coach Jim Mora says his offense is 'putrid.'

High ankle sprain could put USC running back Justin Davis on the shelf for a while.

The Trojans overcome their own mistakes.

The Trojans put themselves back into the Pac-12 South race.

The second half has been a problem for Arizona.

Arizona State could be starting a fourth-stringer at quarterback against Colorado.

The Buffaloes need to put the USC loss behind them.

Remember when Stanford's offensive line was intimidating? Now it's pitiful.

Wilner flunks Stanford's showing against Wazzu.

Cal Poly uses a bye week to prepare for Portland State.

The links from Beaver Sports Now.

The links from Duck Sports Now.

-- Ken Goe

kgoe@oregonian.com

503-221-8040 | @KenGoe
results.title: Rush to condemn Oregon Ducks coach Mark Helfrich is overly simplistic: Issues & Answers
results.html: Oregon's four-game slide has the critics out in force.
results.short_title: Rush to condemn UO coach Mark Helfrich is simplistic: I&A

results.body:
A female student was reportedly harassed by a Donald Trump supporter who shoved her and broke her phone on the Portland State University campus over the weekend, officials said.

On Sunday around 3:30 p.m., the victim, who was not identified, was walking between Stott Field and Hoffman Hall when she was approached by a man with a video camera who asked her if she wanted to be on "Trump TV," the victim wrote in a post on Reddit.

"I said 'no thank you,'" the victim wrote, "and with the camera still in my face he asked me my thoughts on the election. I told him I didn't have time to talk with him at the moment, to which he replied, 'are you a bitch or something?'"

The man then continued berating the victim, including a lewd suggestion about her lipstick color, before she told him she was calling the police. At that point, the man grabbed her phone, threw it to the ground and stepped on it. He then shoved her and threw the phone across the courtyard.

The victim began to scream and a passerby started walking toward the commotion, at which point the man fled east toward Harrison Street, police said.

"I can only imagine what would've happened had this other person not been around," the victim wrote.

University police confirmed they were investigating the incident and said the man was described as between 30 and 40 years old with short hair and a clean shaven face with a scarred complexion. He said to be wearing a green baseball hat, aviator sunglasses and a brown jacket with patches at the time of the incident.

Investigators asked anyone with information about the incident to contact the Campus Public Safety Office at 503-725-4407 or by calling the emergency line at 503-725-4404.

—   Kale Williams

kwilliams@oregonian.com

503-294-4048

@sfkale
results.title: PSU student reports Donald Trump supporter broke her phone, shoved her
results.html: The man allegedly approached the victim and tried to film her for something he called "Trump TV."
results.short_title: PSU student reports Trump supporter broke her phone, shoved her

results.body:
A man robbed and sexually assaulted a person at a Northeast Portland lingerie modeling shop, and police have asked the public for help in finding the suspect.

Officers responded to reports of an armed robbery about 3:15 a.m. Monday at Pussycats, 3414 N.E. 82nd Ave. Police spokesman Sgt. Pete Simpson said officers learned a man in his 20s armed with a gun entered the adult venue and demanded money.

"The suspect sexually assaulted the victim before leaving the business," Simpson said in a news release. Officers searched the neighborhood and didn't find anyone who looked like the suspect.

The tall man with a medium build wore dark clothing and a bandanna covering his face, Simpson said. Investigators don't know if the suspect has been involved in other robberies, he said.

No other information was released. Anyone with information is asked to call robbery detectives at 503-823-0405.

— Tony Hernandez
thernandez@oregonian.com
503-294-5928
@tonyhreports
results.title: Robber sexually assaults victim at lingerie shop, police say
results.html: A man robbed and sexually assaulted a person at a lingerie modeling shop, and police have asked the public for tips in finding the suspect.

results.body:
A woman missing since September chose to leave on her own and wanted to be left alone, the Yamhill County Sheriff's Office said.

Deputies confirmed Jessica Jane Ford Jung, 39, was located safe and in good health after she was last seen Sept. 8 in Lafayette. Jung had been staying with acquaintances before she disappeared.

In late September, the Sheriff's Office announced her disappearance and reported she suffered from a mental health illness. Phone records indicated she could have been in Clackamas County, about 75 miles away.

The Sheriff's Office said another agency found Jung during a "field contact" Monday morning. Sgt. Chris Ray, Sheriff's Office spokesman, declined to say where she was found because she was not in danger and wanted privacy.

— Tony Hernandez
thernandez@oregonian.com
503-294-5928
@tonyhreports
results.title: Woman missing for month found safe, Yamhill County deputies say
results.html: A woman missing since September chose to leave on her own and wanted to be left alone, the Yamhill County Sheriff's Office said.

results.body:
The principal of Lincoln High School in September told administrators that she felt she needed "to retain a lawyer" over "repeated harassment and retaliation" from the Portland school board's vice chair.

The accusation was among more than 200 emails released by Portland Public Schools on Monday, weeks after Lincoln students walked off their campus to protest the board's delay of a $750 million bond measure.

The emails offer fresh insight into tensions that followed the protest, which sparked controversy when the district put Benson High School in "lockout" after Lincoln students showed up outside.

A group of 20, including parents and media organizations, asked for the records Sept. 12. The district released emails, but not text messages also sought from board members. The school district's attorney, Stephanie Harper, said "that request is not denied, however" — but questioned how the request "is related to the public interest."

Lincoln High School Principal Peyton Chapman emailed three high-level district employees after the walkout to document a meeting with them and relay concerns she was being "systematically harassed" by School Board Vice Chair Amy Kohnstamm.

Chapman wrote Kohnstamm "verbally attacked" her after the Sept. 7 lockout for "having the 'highest levels of arrogance' she has ever seen and for not agreeing with her perspective."

Previously, Chapman had publicly urged the board to place the bond on the November ballot. The board, in a 4-3 vote, decided to aim for the May ballot instead.

Chapman said in an interview that she's since told the district to drop the matter and is not pursuing any harassment claims against Kohnstamm.

"That was a really intense time period because we are both really passionate about school facilities and we had different views on the timing of that," Chapman said. "We both realized the most important thing was to advance needed improvements for our schools. We have a history of working really closely together."

Chapman would not detail how the district handled her concerns but said she met with several district officials and felt at ease.

"That was a very stressful day for Peyton and sometimes people say things when emotions are running high," Kohnstamm said in a text message Monday. "She's a terrific principal and we will both devote ourselves to getting our bond passed."

Chapman wrote that she wanted to document, in the meeting with the administrators, that she was told she was being investigated over the walkout.

"You have asked me not to talk to students to avoid perceptions of tainting their testimony which of course I would never do," Chapman wrote. "You also informed me that you would be researching employee's free speech rights as you were not sure what rights principals have."

Antonio Lopez, the district's superintendent for the Office of School Performance, denied Chapman was under investigation in his reply. He was in the meeting along with Senior Director of Schools Oscar Gilson and Director of Academic Programs Greg Wolleck.

"I did not say you are being investigated, what I said was that we are investigating the situation to see how it came about and the lessons we can learn from it," Lopez wrote.

As to Chapman's concerns about Kohnstamm, Lopez wrote that it was his job to relay them to Interim Superintendent Bob McKean.

In her email, Chapman said Kohnstamm had harassed her since Chapman wrote an opinion piece in favor of the November ballot. After the piece ran, Chapman said, Kohnstamm sent her text messages claiming Chapman was trying to "undermine her" and "sabotage her leadership."

The decision to push the bond to May emerged as a flashpoint because board members had been planning until late July to aim for November. The about-face came as a surprise to some in the community — just days before, the board's bond committee had publicly supported a November bond.

Board members were criticized for not publicly discussing the reasoning behind the sudden change and in September, students forced a conversation by threatening a sit-in of a board meeting.

The walkout the next day became controversial when Lincoln students decided to head to Benson. Both schools would benefit from the bond. Police guarded the doors at Benson, and McKean ordered the school under a "lockout" to prevent Lincoln students from entering the school.

The sight of officers outside Benson, and signs inside Benson saying students should remain inside, led students, parents and civil rights groups to question why students at a mostly white, affluent school seemed to be free to protest while a school serving less-privileged students appeared to be holding students hostage.

Administrators said Benson students were free to leave, heightening tensions. Many complained the statement was disingenuous and inaccurate as the signs and the district's own lock out policy stated otherwise.

The emails released Monday show senior administrators sought editing from a communications consultant, Anna Richter Taylor, before releasing a statement on the lockout to students at both schools.

At one point, on Sept. 12, Richter Taylor told district chief of staff Amanda Whalen in an email that "from all press accounts the district looks not so great."

McKean's statement after the unrest acknowledged unclear communication and room for improvement, but maintained the lockout had been the right call at the time and noted the doors were not actually locked.

McKean has since met with student leaders, who have said publicly they're hopeful the incident was a learning experience for the district.

-- Bethany Barnes

bbarnes@oregonian.com
results.title: Emails show tension, rifts in wake of Lincoln High's walkout over bond delay
results.html: The emails offer fresh insight into tensions that followed the protest, which sparked controversy when the district put Benson High School in "lockout" after Lincoln students showed up outside.
results.short_title: Emails show tension, rifts in wake of Lincoln High walkout

results.body:
Otoniel Hernandez-DuarteGresham Police Department 

Police have identified the man killed Sunday morning in Gresham as a 19-year-old Portland resident.

Otoniel Hernandez-Duarte died of multiple stab wounds, Gresham police said in a news release. Ariana Marlene Cortez of Gresham, 19, is facing a murder charge in his death, court records show.

Cortez is friends with Hernandez-Duarte's significant other, according to processing documents filed Monday in Multnomah County Circuit Court. Police said Cortez and Hernandez-Duarte were acquaintances, from what investigators have determined. 

Cortez lives in the 1200 block of Northeast 183rd Avenue, where police said they were called shortly after 4:30 a.m. Sunday.

An officer found Hernandez-Duarte on the floor just inside the front door of a duplex, according to a probable cause affidavit filed Monday in Multnomah County Circuit Court. He was bleeding heavily from a wound in his neck area and didn't have a pulse.

None of the adults at the home knew Hernandez-Duarte before he knocked on the duplex door, according to the affidavit. One woman said she heard a disturbance next door before Hernandez-Duarte came knocking.

The adjacent duplex unit — which Cortez is leasing — had a broken window, and its front door was ajar. Police didn't find anyone inside.

Ariana Marlene CortezMCSO 

A neighbor who has a view of the front door of the duplex unit with the broken window told an Oregon State Police detective that several loud noises woke him in the early morning. He said he looked outside and saw a man on the unit's porch.

The man on the porch broke a window, the neighbor told the detective, and a woman opened the door, yelled at the man and pushed him down. A police spokesman said it appears Hernandez-Duarte is the man who broke the window.

The neighbor said he started getting dressed and turned his attention from the altercation, and he later saw four or five people exit the unit and leave in a SUV. 

A detective phoned Cortez later that morning, and she later agreed to meet him for an interview, according to the affidavit. She wasn't under arrest at the beginning of the interview.

Cortez told the detective she hosted a party Saturday for the child of one of her friends and that the party kept going past midnight. She said "Tony Hernandez" was at the party and that he was "going crazy" — breaking decorations and throwing beer cans.

She said she shocked him with a Taser twice and that the shocks didn't affect him, according to the affidavit.

Hernandez-Duarte was often referred to as "Tony," his mother told police.

Cortez told the detective that "someone" broke her window while she was home alone and that the person who broke her window had a knife. She got a knife from her kitchen.

She said she blacked out once she got the knife and that she didn't remember what happened. 

Another detective interviewed Cortez's mother, and she told him that she picked up Cortez at a gas station on the day of the killing after Cortez called her and said "something bad happened."

She said Cortez told her she asked a man to leave her party and that he wouldn't do so. She said Cortez told her the man was threatening her with a knife, that they fought outside in some way, that Cortez went into her kitchen and that Cortez eventually stabbed the man.

Officer John Rasmussen, a Gresham police spokesman, said investigators haven't confirmed Cortez was threatened with a knife.

Gresham police arrested Cortez in the killing, and she was booked into the Multnomah County Detention Center around 1 a.m. Monday. She was arraigned Monday and is scheduled to next appear in court Oct. 18, according to court records.

She's being held in the jail without bail, records show.

Gresham police ask anyone who has information about the killing to call the department's tip line, 503-618-2719.

— Jim Ryan
jryan@oregonian.com
503-221-8005; @Jimryan015
results.title: Portland man, 19, stabbed to death in Gresham: police
results.html: Otoniel Hernandez-Duarte was stabbed to death, according to Gresham police.

results.body:
The Oregon State Beavers showed signs of progress over the weekend, as coach Gary Andersen registered his first Pac-12 win with a 47-44 overtime victory over Cal.

That feat not only made an impression with the official visitors recruits that were in Corvallis, but also a few of Oregon State's key targets.

On Monday, former Western Oregon and current Palomar offensive tackle Justin Sattelmaier decided to end his recruitment, committing to the Beavers over heavy interest from Colorado, Purdue and San Diego State. 

"It's a blessing. Coach Andersen called me (last week) and offered me. It's crazy that they were that impressed with what I've done," he said. "I worked hard for it, and I have to thank my family, my brother and my coaches for all they taught me and for believing in me."

For Sattelmaier, who has three years to play three, the key factor was the honest approach Andersen and his staff took. He decided to reward that honesty before taking his official visit for the Civil War game later this season.

In order to become a Pac-12 football player, Sattelmaier had to endure a circuitous route and two difficult comebacks from knee injuries.

After tearing his ACL as a junior, the offensive lineman missed the start of his senior season in high school, then tore his meniscus shortly after returning.

Despite limited film, Western Oregon believed in Sattelmaier enough to give him a chance and he enrolled.

"I didn't really like the school. It was small and a lot of people went home," he said. "When I played there, I planned on staying there all five years. It was still college football and still a blessing to play."

But the itch to try to aim for something more never left him, and Sattelmaier decided to head to Palomar College (San Marcos, California) in the hopes of impressing an FCS or FBS program.

Just five games in to his junior college season, Oregon State called and pulled the trigger, offering the behemoth a scholarship.

Sattelmaier is expected to come in an compete for the back-up role at either left or right tackle, but could earn a starting spot as he develops.

For Oregon State, the commitment marks the third offensive line pledge in the class of 2017, joining Central Catholic's Travis Mackay and Washington product Brock Wellsfry.

-- Andrew Nemec
anemec@oregonian.com
@AndrewNemec
results.title: Justin Sattelmaier, 6-foot-7, 300-pound JC OL, commits to Oregon State Beavers
results.html: Justin Sattelmaier slid in under the radar after injuries his junior and senior year of high school

results.body:
Taking a $916 million tax-loss carryforward, possibly allowing you to avoid paying federal income taxes for two decades? Everybody does it!

So went Donald Trump's argument Sunday when he was asked about his 1995 federal tax return, which was leaked to the press last week. "Warren Buffett took a massive deduction," the Republican nominee said during the second presidential debate.

Really? Buffett, the billionaire investor known as the "Oracle of Omaha," wants to set the record straight.

"Mr. Trump says he knows more about taxes than any other human," Buffett said in a statement on Monday. "He has not seen my income tax returns. But I am happy to give him the facts."

Buffett says he has paid federal income tax every year since he was 13 years old -- that is, since 1944. "I have copies of all 72 of my returns and none uses a carryforward," he said.

Buffett, who backs Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton and whose outrage at tax loopholes for the wealthy inspired the "Buffett Rule" (a proposal that would require anyone making $1 million or more to pay at least 30 percent of their income in federal taxes), also called on Trump to release his tax returns. Trump, who says he will not release his returns because he's under federal audit, is the first major-party presidential nominee in more than 30 years to keep his taxes under wraps.

"I have been audited by the IRS multiple times and am currently being audited," Buffett said. "I have no problem in releasing my tax information while under audit. Neither would Mr. Trump -- at least he would have no legal problem."

 -- Douglas Perry
results.title: Warren Buffett hits Donald Trump over taxes explanation, calls for Trump to release his returns
results.html: Taking a $916 million income-tax-loss carryforward, possibly allowing you to avoid paying federal income taxes for two decades? Everybody does it!
results.short_title: Warren Buffett hits Donald Trump over taxes explanation

results.body:
For the second consecutive year, the Oregon Ducks set up a huge recruiting weekend for its top recruits.

And for the second time, Oregon laid an egg, as ESPN's Erik McKinney pointed out in an article about the back-to-back disastrous official visit plans.

As McKinney explained, last year the Ducks loaded up their top defensive recruits for official visits against Utah, who then watched the Utes throttle them, 62-20.

This weekend, it was more of the same.

With the nation's No. 1 wide receiver and middle linebacker and several more standouts in Eugene, Oregon fell to Washington 70-21.

This time around, key in-state target Elijah Molden said it was "tough to imagine" the blowout didn't hurt the recruiting effort.

The end result is yet to be determined, but the strategy has been a misfire thus far.

Here's a look at the top recruiting stories of the past few days:

Oregon Ducks

- Analysis: Can Oregon Ducks defensive slide be explained by recruiting?

- Elijah Molden on Oregon Ducks official visit: 'Tough to imagine' blowout didn't hurt recruiting

- Oregon Ducks: Nation's top WR, MLB highlight huge recruiting weekend

- Oregon Ducks 4-star commit Jaylon Redd scores five touchdowns, two on kick/punt returns, in impressive showing

- 3 Oregon Ducks defensive commits selected as U.S. Army All-Americans

- Q&A: 2018 Oregon Ducks 4-star QB commit Colson Yankoff talks recruitment, future of coaching staff

- 2018 five-star SF Emmanuel Akot names top 4; Oregon Ducks make cut

Oregon State Beavers

- 6-foot-7, 300-pound JC OL Justin Sattelmaier commits to Oregon State Beavers

- Oregon State Beavers pursuing impressive list of JC talent

- Analysis: Would focusing on junior college talent be good for Oregon State Beavers? 

- Recruiting: Oregon State Beavers hosting offensive playmakers, JC talent

- 2018 4-star center Jack Wilson high on Oregon State Beavers, Wayne Tinkle

- Wilsonville SG Zach Reichle set to commit next week; Oregon State Beavers among top contenders

-- Andrew Nemec
anemec@oregonian.com
@AndrewNemec
results.title: Recruiting roundup: Ducks hurt by blowout loss; Beavers land massive JC OL
results.html: A look at the top Oregon, Oregon State recruiting stories of the past few days
